title: 112_hr915
content: The Act titled the "Jaime Zapata Border Enforcement Security Task Force Act" aims to address the surge in border crime and violence on Mexico's northern border with the United States. This is due to competition between Mexican drug cartels and criminal smuggling organizations. United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) plays a crucial role in enforcing laws related to border security and combating criminal smuggling. The Border Enforcement Security Task Force (BEST) initiative was created by DHS to address border security threats by partnering with various law enforcement agencies. BEST teams include personnel from ICE, CBP, DEA, ATFE, FBI, USCG, and the U.S. Attorney's Office to increase information-sharing and collaboration. The Border Enforcement Security Task Force (BEST) initiative, established by DHS, partners with various law enforcement agencies including ICE, CBP, DEA, ATFE, FBI, USCG, and the U.S. Attorney's Office. Foreign agencies like Mexico's SSP, Canada's CBSA, OPP, and RCMP also participate in BEST to enhance border security. BEST aims to address and reduce border security threats through collaboration and information-sharing. The Border Enforcement Security Task Force (BEST) initiative aims to enhance border security by collaborating with various law enforcement agencies to address and reduce threats and violence. BEST units may consist of personnel from ICE, CBP, USCG, other federal agencies, state law enforcement agencies, and foreign law enforcement agencies. The BEST initiative aims to enhance border security by collaborating with various law enforcement agencies to establish BEST units in jurisdictions significantly impacted by cross-border threats. The Secretary considers factors such as the availability of law enforcement resources and the harmful impact of border security threats before establishing a BEST unit. The Secretary determines the establishment of BEST units in jurisdictions impacted by cross-border threats, considering factors like available resources and existing interagency task forces. Federal personnel may be assigned to BEST for assistance with approval from their respective department or agency heads. The Secretary will take actions to assist various law enforcement agencies in participating in BEST, including providing financial assistance for operational costs. A report will be submitted to Congress every year for 5 years to evaluate BEST's effectiveness in enhancing border security and reducing crime along the international borders of the United States. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include statistics on violent deaths, incidents of violence, and drug-related arrests. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a new section, Sec. 432, which establishes the Border Enforcement Security Task Force.
